1.verse: The words of the Teacher,  ( A ) son of David, king in Jerusalem: ( B )

3.verse: What do people gain from all their labors

5.verse: The sun rises and the sun sets,

6.verse: The wind blows to the south

7.verse: All streams flow into the sea,

9.verse: What has been will be again,

10.verse: Is there anything of which one can say,

11.verse: No one remembers the former generations, ( J )

12.verse: I, the Teacher, ( L ) was king over Israel in Jerusalem. ( M )

13.verse: I applied my mind to study and to explore by wisdom all that is done under the heavens. ( N ) What a heavy burden God has laid on mankind! ( O )

14.verse: I have seen all the things that are done under the sun; all of them are meaningless, a chasing after the wind. ( P )

15.verse: What is crooked cannot be straightened; ( Q )

16.verse: I said to myself, “Look, I have increased in wisdom more than anyone who has ruled over Jerusalem before me; ( R ) I have experienced much of wisdom and knowledge.”

17.verse: Then I applied myself to the understanding of wisdom, ( S ) and also of madness and folly, ( T ) but I learned that this, too, is a chasing after the wind.

18.verse: For with much wisdom comes much sorrow; ( U )

1.verse: I said to myself, “Come now, I will test you with pleasure ( A ) to find out what is good.” But that also proved to be meaningless.

2.verse: “Laughter,” ( B ) I said, “is madness. And what does pleasure accomplish?”

3.verse: I tried cheering myself with wine, ( C ) and embracing folly ( D ) —my mind still guiding me with wisdom. I wanted to see what was good for people to do under the heavens during the few days of their lives.

4.verse: I undertook great projects: I built houses for myself ( E ) and planted vineyards. ( F )

5.verse: I made gardens and parks and planted all kinds of fruit trees in them.

6.verse: I made reservoirs to water groves of flourishing trees.

7.verse: I bought male and female slaves and had other slaves ( G ) who were born in my house. I also owned more herds and flocks than anyone in Jerusalem before me.

8.verse: I amassed silver and gold ( H ) for myself, and the treasure of kings and provinces. ( I ) I acquired male and female singers, ( J ) and a harem  as well—the delights of a man’s heart.

9.verse: I became greater by far than anyone in Jerusalem ( K ) before me. ( L ) In all this my wisdom stayed with me.

10.verse: I denied myself nothing my eyes desired;

11.verse: Yet when I surveyed all that my hands had done

12.verse: Then I turned my thoughts to consider wisdom,

13.verse: I saw that wisdom ( Q ) is better than folly, ( R )

14.verse: The wise have eyes in their heads,

16.verse: For the wise, like the fool, will not be long remembered; ( U )

17.verse: So I hated life, because the work that is done under the sun was grievous to me. All of it is meaningless, a chasing after the wind. ( X )

18.verse: I hated all the things I had toiled for under the sun, because I must leave them to the one who comes after me. ( Y )

19.verse: And who knows whether that person will be wise or foolish? ( Z ) Yet they will have control over all the fruit of my toil into which I have poured my effort and skill under the sun. This too is meaningless.

20.verse: So my heart began to despair over all my toilsome labor under the sun.

21.verse: For a person may labor with wisdom, knowledge and skill, and then they must leave all they own to another who has not toiled for it. This too is meaningless and a great misfortune.

22.verse: What do people get for all the toil and anxious striving with which they labor under the sun? ( AA )

23.verse: All their days their work is grief and pain; ( AB ) even at night their minds do not rest. ( AC ) This too is meaningless.

24.verse: A person can do nothing better than to eat and drink ( AD ) and find satisfaction in their own toil. ( AE ) This too, I see, is from the hand of God, ( AF )

25.verse: for without him, who can eat or find enjoyment? ( AG )

26.verse: To the person who pleases him, God gives wisdom, ( AH ) knowledge and happiness, but to the sinner he gives the task of gathering and storing up wealth ( AI ) to hand it over to the one who pleases God. ( AJ ) This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.

1.verse: There is a time ( A ) for everything,

2.verse: a time to be born and a time to die,

3.verse: a time to kill ( C ) and a time to heal,

4.verse: a time to weep and a time to laugh,

5.verse: a time to scatter stones and a time to gather them,

6.verse: a time to search and a time to give up,

7.verse: a time to tear and a time to mend,

8.verse: a time to love and a time to hate,

9.verse: What do workers gain from their toil? ( E )

10.verse: I have seen the burden God has laid on the human race. ( F )

11.verse: He has made everything beautiful in its time. ( G ) He has also set eternity in the human heart; yet  no one can fathom ( H ) what God has done from beginning to end. ( I )

12.verse: I know that there is nothing better for people than to be happy and to do good while they live.

13.verse: That each of them may eat and drink, ( J ) and find satisfaction ( K ) in all their toil—this is the gift of God. ( L )

14.verse: I know that everything God does will endure forever; nothing can be added to it and nothing taken from it. God does it so that people will fear him. ( M )

15.verse: Whatever is has already been, ( N )

16.verse: And I saw something else under the sun:

18.verse: I also said to myself, “As for humans, God tests them so that they may see that they are like the animals. ( R )

19.verse: Surely the fate of human beings ( S ) is like that of the animals; the same fate awaits them both: As one dies, so dies the other. All have the same breath  ; humans have no advantage over animals. Everything is meaningless.

20.verse: All go to the same place; all come from dust, and to dust all return. ( T )

21.verse: Who knows if the human spirit rises upward ( U ) and if the spirit of the animal goes down into the earth?”

22.verse: So I saw that there is nothing better for a person than to enjoy their work, ( V ) because that is their lot. ( W ) For who can bring them to see what will happen after them?

1.verse: Again I looked and saw all the oppression ( A ) that was taking place under the sun:

2.verse: And I declared that the dead, ( C )

4.verse: And I saw that all toil and all achievement spring from one person’s envy of another. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind. ( G )

7.verse: Again I saw something meaningless under the sun:

8.verse: There was a man all alone;

10.verse: If either of them falls down,

11.verse: Also, if two lie down together, they will keep warm.

13.verse: Better a poor but wise youth than an old but foolish king who no longer knows how to heed a warning.

14.verse: The youth may have come from prison to the kingship, or he may have been born in poverty within his kingdom.

15.verse: I saw that all who lived and walked under the sun followed the youth, the king’s successor.

16.verse: There was no end to all the people who were before them. But those who came later were not pleased with the successor. This too is meaningless, a chasing after the wind.

1.verse: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God. Go near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools, who do not know that they do wrong.

2.verse: Do not be quick with your mouth,

3.verse: A dream ( C ) comes when there are many cares,

4.verse: When you make a vow to God, do not delay to fulfill it. ( E ) He has no pleasure in fools; fulfill your vow. ( F )

5.verse: It is better not to make a vow than to make one and not fulfill it. ( G )

6.verse: Do not let your mouth lead you into sin. And do not protest to the temple messenger, “My vow was a mistake.” Why should God be angry at what you say and destroy the work of your hands?

7.verse: Much dreaming and many words are meaningless. Therefore fear God. ( H )

8.verse: If you see the poor oppressed ( I ) in a district, and justice and rights denied, do not be surprised at such things; for one official is eyed by a higher one, and over them both are others higher still.

9.verse: The increase from the land is taken by all; the king himself profits from the fields.

10.verse: Whoever loves money never has enough;

12.verse: The sleep of a laborer is sweet,

13.verse: I have seen a grievous evil under the sun: ( K )

14.verse: or wealth lost through some misfortune,

15.verse: Everyone comes naked from their mother’s womb,

16.verse: This too is a grievous evil:

17.verse: All their days they eat in darkness,

18.verse: This is what I have observed to be good: that it is appropriate for a person to eat, to drink ( P ) and to find satisfaction in their toilsome labor ( Q ) under the sun during the few days of life God has given them—for this is their lot.

19.verse: Moreover, when God gives someone wealth and possessions, ( R ) and the ability to enjoy them, ( S ) to accept their lot ( T ) and be happy in their toil—this is a gift of God. ( U )

20.verse: They seldom reflect on the days of their life, because God keeps them occupied with gladness of heart. ( V )

1.verse: I have seen another evil under the sun, and it weighs heavily on mankind:

2.verse: God gives some people wealth, possessions and honor, so that they lack nothing their hearts desire, but God does not grant them the ability to enjoy them, ( A ) and strangers enjoy them instead. This is meaningless, a grievous evil. ( B )

3.verse: A man may have a hundred children and live many years; yet no matter how long he lives, if he cannot enjoy his prosperity and does not receive proper burial, I say that a stillborn ( C ) child is better off than he. ( D )

4.verse: It comes without meaning, it departs in darkness, and in darkness its name is shrouded.

5.verse: Though it never saw the sun or knew anything, it has more rest than does that man—

6.verse: even if he lives a thousand years twice over but fails to enjoy his prosperity. Do not all go to the same place? ( E )

7.verse: Everyone’s toil is for their mouth,

8.verse: What advantage have the wise over fools? ( G )

10.verse: Whatever exists has already been named, ( I )

12.verse: For who knows what is good for a person in life, during the few and meaningless days ( J ) they pass through like a shadow? ( K ) Who can tell them what will happen under the sun after they are gone?

1.verse: A good name is better than fine perfume, ( A )

2.verse: It is better to go to a house of mourning

3.verse: Frustration is better than laughter, ( E )

4.verse: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning,

5.verse: It is better to heed the rebuke ( G ) of a wise person

6.verse: Like the crackling of thorns ( H ) under the pot,

7.verse: Extortion turns a wise person into a fool,

8.verse: The end of a matter is better than its beginning,

9.verse: Do not be quickly provoked ( L ) in your spirit,

10.verse: Do not say, “Why were the old days ( N ) better than these?”

11.verse: Wisdom, like an inheritance, is a good thing ( O )

13.verse: Consider what God has done: ( Q )

14.verse: When times are good, be happy;

15.verse: In this meaningless life ( T ) of mine I have seen both of these:

18.verse: It is good to grasp the one

19.verse: Wisdom ( X ) makes one wise person more powerful ( Y )

20.verse: Indeed, there is no one on earth who is righteous, ( Z )

21.verse: Do not pay attention to every word people say,

22.verse: for you know in your heart

23.verse: All this I tested by wisdom and I said,

24.verse: Whatever exists is far off and most profound—

25.verse: So I turned my mind to understand,

26.verse: I find more bitter than death

27.verse: “Look,” says the Teacher,  ( AI ) “this is what I have discovered:

2.verse: Obey the king’s command, I say, because you took an oath before God.

3.verse: Do not be in a hurry to leave the king’s presence. ( A ) Do not stand up for a bad cause, for he will do whatever he pleases.

4.verse: Since a king’s word is supreme, who can say to him, “What are you doing? ( B ) ”

5.verse: Whoever obeys his command will come to no harm,

6.verse: For there is a proper time and procedure for every matter, ( C )

7.verse: Since no one knows the future,

8.verse: As no one has power over the wind to contain it,

9.verse: All this I saw, as I applied my mind to everything done under the sun. There is a time when a man lords it over others to his own  hurt.

10.verse: Then too, I saw the wicked buried ( D ) —those who used to come and go from the holy place and receive praise  in the city where they did this. This too is meaningless.

11.verse: When the sentence for a crime is not quickly carried out, people’s hearts are filled with schemes to do wrong.

12.verse: Although a wicked person who commits a hundred crimes may live a long time, I know that it will go better ( E ) with those who fear God, ( F ) who are reverent before him. ( G )

13.verse: Yet because the wicked do not fear God, ( H ) it will not go well with them, and their days ( I ) will not lengthen like a shadow.

14.verse: There is something else meaningless that occurs on earth: the righteous who get what the wicked deserve, and the wicked who get what the righteous deserve. ( J ) This too, I say, is meaningless. ( K )

15.verse: So I commend the enjoyment of life ( L ) , because there is nothing better for a person under the sun than to eat and drink ( M ) and be glad. ( N ) Then joy will accompany them in their toil all the days of the life God has given them under the sun.

16.verse: When I applied my mind to know wisdom ( O ) and to observe the labor that is done on earth ( P ) —people getting no sleep day or night—

17.verse: then I saw all that God has done. ( Q ) No one can comprehend what goes on under the sun. Despite all their efforts to search it out, no one can discover its meaning. Even if the wise claim they know, they cannot really comprehend it. ( R )

1.verse: So I reflected on all this and concluded that the righteous and the wise and what they do are in God’s hands, but no one knows whether love or hate awaits them. ( A )

2.verse: All share a common destiny—the righteous and the wicked, the good and the bad,  the clean and the unclean, those who offer sacrifices and those who do not.

3.verse: This is the evil in everything that happens under the sun: The same destiny overtakes all. ( C ) The hearts of people, moreover, are full of evil and there is madness in their hearts while they live, ( D ) and afterward they join the dead. ( E )

4.verse: Anyone who is among the living has hope  —even a live dog is better off than a dead lion!

5.verse: For the living know that they will die,

7.verse: Go, eat your food with gladness, and drink your wine ( J ) with a joyful heart, ( K ) for God has already approved what you do.

8.verse: Always be clothed in white, ( L ) and always anoint your head with oil.

9.verse: Enjoy life with your wife, ( M ) whom you love, all the days of this meaningless life that God has given you under the sun—all your meaningless days. For this is your lot ( N ) in life and in your toilsome labor under the sun.

10.verse: Whatever ( O ) your hand finds to do, do it with all your might, ( P ) for in the realm of the dead, ( Q ) where you are going, there is neither working nor planning nor knowledge nor wisdom. ( R )

11.verse: I have seen something else under the sun:

12.verse: Moreover, no one knows when their hour will come:

13.verse: I also saw under the sun this example of wisdom ( Y ) that greatly impressed me:

14.verse: There was once a small city with only a few people in it. And a powerful king came against it, surrounded it and built huge siege works against it.

15.verse: Now there lived in that city a man poor but wise, and he saved the city by his wisdom. But nobody remembered that poor man. ( Z )

16.verse: So I said, “Wisdom is better than strength.” But the poor man’s wisdom is despised, and his words are no longer heeded. ( AA )

17.verse: The quiet words of the wise are more to be heeded

18.verse: Wisdom ( AB ) is better than weapons of war,

1.verse: As dead flies give perfume a bad smell,

2.verse: The heart of the wise inclines to the right,

3.verse: Even as fools walk along the road,

4.verse: If a ruler’s anger rises against you,

5.verse: There is an evil I have seen under the sun,

6.verse: Fools are put in many high positions, ( E )

7.verse: I have seen slaves on horseback,

8.verse: Whoever digs a pit may fall into it; ( G )

9.verse: Whoever quarries stones may be injured by them;

11.verse: If a snake bites before it is charmed,

12.verse: Words from the mouth of the wise are gracious, ( K )

13.verse: At the beginning their words are folly;

15.verse: The toil of fools wearies them;

16.verse: Woe to the land whose king was a servant  ( O )

17.verse: Blessed is the land whose king is of noble birth

19.verse: A feast is made for laughter,

20.verse: Do not revile the king ( S ) even in your thoughts,

1.verse: Ship ( A ) your grain across the sea;

2.verse: Invest in seven ventures, yes, in eight;

3.verse: If clouds are full of water,

4.verse: Whoever watches the wind will not plant;

5.verse: As you do not know the path of the wind, ( C )

6.verse: Sow your seed in the morning,

8.verse: However many years anyone may live,

9.verse: You who are young, be happy while you are young,

10.verse: So then, banish anxiety ( I ) from your heart

2.verse: before the sun and the light

3.verse: when the keepers of the house tremble,

4.verse: when the doors to the street are closed

5.verse: when people are afraid of heights

6.verse: Remember him—before the silver cord is severed,

7.verse: and the dust returns ( F ) to the ground it came from,

9.verse: Not only was the Teacher wise, but he also imparted knowledge to the people. He pondered and searched out and set in order many proverbs. ( K )

10.verse: The Teacher ( L ) searched to find just the right words, and what he wrote was upright and true. ( M )

11.verse: The words of the wise are like goads, their collected sayings like firmly embedded nails ( N ) —given by one shepherd.

12.verse: Be warned, my son, of anything in addition to them.

14.verse: For God will bring every deed into judgment, ( S )
